Award.AwardTitle: Group Travel Grant for the Doctoral Consortium of the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant partially supports the participation of students from US institutions in the Doctoral Consortium at the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) 2017 in Honolulu, Hawaii. CVPR is the premier annual conference in computer vision with over 2000 senior, junior and student participants. It is held in North America and attended by members of the international research community. The broader impacts of this project include supporting the career development of some of the brightest junior researchers in computer vision, contributing to the research community in general by drawing attention to an important aspect of graduate student development, potentially increasing the number of active researchers and educators in STEM, and ensuring that the computer vision community, through its recent graduates, makes fast advances in solving problems that will benefit society as a whole. The Doctoral Consortium aims to have representation from a diverse group of participants in terms of gender, ethnic background, academic institution, and geographic location.

NSF support covers some of the costs for 15 selected US-based graduate students to attend the conference. Participants and recipients of travel support are selected by the 2017 CVPR Doctoral Consortium co-chairs. The Doctoral Consortium provides opportunities for senior PhD students to highlight their work, and to discuss their research and career options with faculty and researchers who have relevant expertise and experience. The opportunity to receive advice on their research work and career plans from experts from different institutions, and with potentially different perspectives, is often not available internally at one's own institution. This year's Doctoral Consortium features a poster session, one-on-one mentoring, and panel discussion. The last of these components was introduced in last year's event and was well-received.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to provide mentorship to senior PhD students in computer vision, and increase their visibility in the research community. This mentorship took place at the Doctoral Consortium event held in conjunction with the 2017 IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR). The award for this project provided partial travel support for 15 students at US universities.

The mentorship by established senior researchers, and the networking opportunities that the event provides, are not available at one's own institution. The event benefits both the young researchers, and the computer vision community as a whole by helping these young researchers achieve their full potential and apply their skills in the most appropriate career path. It also benefits society through the potential high-impact computer vision applications that these researchers create.

Graduate student participants submitted applications highlighting their research and publications. Admitted applicants were matched with mentors for which they expressed preference. The list of mentors included both faculty and industry researchers. During the Doctoral Consortium event, held during lunch on the third main conference day, the participants presented their work to their mentors in poster format, then discussed career opportunities with their mentors. A panel was also held where five senior researchers from academia and industry answered commonly asked questions. The student participants' names were provided in the conference program and online, and their CVs were made available by request, thus increasing their visibility further to both other researchers and potential employers.

The participants' feedback on the event was largely very positive. Some ideas for future issues include increasing the time allotted for the consortium, adjusting the presentation format to slides instead of posters, and (also) targetting students who are earlier in their career.
